section.title: Helpful Sites
section.para: A call to a site, from the site's perspective, has three possible outcomes: the site will definitely publish a value, the site knows that it will never publish a value, and the site does not know if it will ever publish a value. For example, a call to Ift(true) publishes a signal, Ift(false) never publishes, and c.get() on channel c that is currently empty may eventually publish or remain non-responsive, depending on whether a value is put in c in the future.

All sites respond with a value when they publish. A helpful site, additionally, responds with an indication that it will never publish when it knows this outcome. All library sites in Orc are helpful. Thus, Ift is a helpful site, and Ift(false) sends an indication to the caller that it will never publish. A buffer is a helpful site, and some of its methods will send an indication that they will never publish. Note that get method on a buffer never sends an indication that will not publish, because it can not definitely determine this outcome; this outcome depends on whether some caller puts an item in the buffer eventually. Thus, get may be blocked permanently.
We do not expect arbitrary web services to be helpful. The indication from a helpful site that it will never publish can be exploited in the caller using the otherwise combinator.
